reviewText:
You can literally punch Satan so hard he explodes.

I could stop the review right there, 'nuff said. Except no, there's so much more to it than that. Broforce is more than just a one-track gag, it's a love letter to 80s and 90s action heroes wrapped in an homage to Contra, Metal Slug, and with a little Worms for good measure.

At first glance, the game may come off as simply a novelty. But they didn't just take a generic character, slap the name Rambro on him, and call it good. Every single character in the cast of over 30 has a great deal of love and detail worked into them. Each character has a unique primary attack, a special attack, and a melee attack. Rambro has a trusty machine gun and versatile grenades, whereas Bro Heart has a claymore and the ability to scare enemies by screaming at the top of his lungs. If a character is played by Van Damme, you better believe he can deliver split kicks to terrorists' faces.

Therein lies Broforce's gimmick:" You start each level with a single life and a random Bro you've unlocked so far. Freeing a Bro trapped in a cage will grant you another life
date: while also swapping your character to another random Bro. Thus
recommended: you have to decide between keeping your current character
hoursPlayed: or getting the extra life. It's a simple mechanic when you get down to it
voteText: but it adds a huge amount of replay value to the game - You'll rarely beat a given level the same way twice.\n\nEach character
helpfulPercent: given that they're completely different

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broforce was my first impulse purchase when I got into PC gaming last summer and I don't regret it at all.
---
Broforce is not the most sophisticated game. A story is non-existent and there's not much motivation beyond rescue the hostages and kill the bad guys. But that's not much of a negative at all, because the gameplay blows away any wishes for a story or deeper motives. Broforce set out to be an ode to 80's and 90's action movies, the Expendables in video game form, and it succeeds on every possible level.

The biggest selling point is the characters, all pixel-art parodies of 80's and 90's action movie heroes. Rambo, Commando, Walker Texas Ranger, Snake Plissken, John McClane, The Terminator, Judge Dredd, and more are available to play as and each with their own unique weapon and secondary explosive. You start each level off as a random hero and can switch to another by rescuing hostages, similar to the weapon swapping mechanic in Super Crate Box.

Each level is a fully destructible playground filled with explosive barrels, propane canisters, and many many enemies ranging from simple goons to suicide bombers to guard dogs and mini-gun wielding mini-bosses. The stylized graphics are nicely detailed, with blood, dirt, smoke, and fire flying with every explosion. The destructible environments adds an layer of depth, allowing you to tunnel beneath enemies to flank them or collapse the ground under their feet or crush them beneath trucks and heavy debris. All those tricks and fast reflexes will be needed because the game is not easy. You die in one hit.
---
Those impressions are months old, but remain as true as ever. Broforce is hard, it's chaotic, it's challenging, it's fun as hell. You feel like a badass, but you also havve to plan your attack because you can die so fast. A lot of times, rushing in will get you killed, while it would be better to flank from above or blow the ground away from below.

Since I wrote that, new heroes have been added, from Neo to Machete. New bosses and challenging new enemies and mini-bosses to fight. New levels and mechanics. The editor has been improved and expanded. Unlike the majority of betas, this feels like a finished games that gets big content updates rather than a skeleton of a game missing critical features like some Early Access games.

So the bottom line: Broforce is a mother♥♥♥♥ing blast and you should play it if you like fast arcade action with highly destructive environments and the chance to play as your favorite action heroes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Edited to make it more helpful*

I've had this game 10 minutes. Why have I only had this game 10 minutes?

This is incredibly, incredibly good. The first Early Access game I've bought and not regretted.

I agree with the comparisons to Contra and Metal Slug. As frantic as Pineapple Smash Crew and just as explody, Zaney and Gory like Metal Slug and Contra respectively.

For such an early version, there's a good deal of content (2 hours for the 'campaign') and plenty of interesting characters to play as.

Replaying with the unlocked characters and trying new and interesting ways to mush enemies is really, really fun.

Oh, and you get to play as Judge Dredd.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broforce made me the man I am today. It taught me courage. Honor. Respect. A secret hybrid of those three. It also grew hair on my chest.

I mean, I already had some, but it grew more. Like twenty handlebar mustaches worth.

Broforce is better than your Dad. Broforce will cure your impotence. In fact, it makes you so potent, that women within a twenty mile radius of you will find themselves pregnant.

When those babies are born, they will emerge as fully grown men, complete with Aviator Sunglasses, a fully loaded M60, and a nice crisp glass of scotch on the rocks. They will speak in high-fives only, and the ground will quake at their presence.

200/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't get my playtime wrong, we here at my apartment have spent HUNDREDS of hours in this game while we weren't able to afford internet. Hands down at the top of my list for couch co-op games. It's so good my wife even begs to play on some days (she is absolutely not a gamer and actually hates games).

A typical day off work for us here at our place:
Invite some bros over
We order pizza
Eat munchies
Start up broforce...and before you know it -birds are chirping, sun is out, and you have to wake up in 3 hours to go to work - and you don't even care, you had a blast - this is THAT Kind of game...

The gameplay is fantastic. The campaign is a blast. Explosion runs are races that are challenging and fun. Don't even get me started on deathmatch! We all get so competitive, it's crazy. I recommend if you are new to broforce, PLEASE don't spoil the surprise of looking at all the character unlocks. We had fun calling them out and being surprised just by that element alone. Each character has different weapons, grenades and abilities - some extremely more powerful than others, but they are all evenly balanced for deathmatch.

I've even been invited to a really lame party a while back, so I whipped out my laptop from my backpack, hooked up broforce to their flatscreen - ♥♥♥♥ got intense. If you read most of these reviews, they are all trying to be funny, since the theme of the game is democracy, and liberating vietnam, and spreading love for 'murica... however they aren't being very helpful in describing the product. I think i've accurately described one of the best games on the market. This game will make your cheeks hurt from smiling and laughing all night. Expendabros is NOTHING compared to the real deal here... But if you haven't gotten it yet - this is best played with real friends, side by side. I use logitech F310's and they work perfectly. Trust me. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Get mission -> kill bad guys -> rescue good guys -> kill big bad guy -> ride helicopter into sunset. This is the action movie archetype, the reason we sit in cinemas summer after summer—a plotline now so mechanical, that Free Lives went ahead and turned it into a mechanic.

It’s how every single level of Broforce’s technically endless campaign plays out (a level editor and custom playlists back up the sizeable main game). Like any action movie, the details might alter. Sometimes you’re taking one of those massive, diagonally-moving lifts you only ever see in evil labs rather than grabbing a chopper-lifted ladder, but the effect is the same

In fact, this is Broforce’s entire design outlook. It pilfers from action movies, and uses their familiarity to build an immediately readable take on the accepted run ‘n’ gun genre—all pixels, enemy screams and one-shot-one-death twitchery.

The playable bros" are Broforce's most obvious references. You play as a line-up of real action stars disguised behind increased muscle mass and names with “Bro” clumsily wedged into them. John Rambro
recommended: Broheart. Every one of the game’s tens of characters is pacey
hoursPlayed: can climb any surface infinitely
voteText: and comes with primary
helpfulPercent: secondary and melee weapons. But they can play totally differently—the brilliance here being that
votesHelpful: if you’re au fait with the action film canon
votesTotal: you’ll have a handle on how they’ll work

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BroForce is the most manly, american side scrolling shooter ever made, ever.



BroForce’s story for the most part is a group of high end soldiers called “Bros” travelling through a wide variety of areas within the campaign, directed by an old white guy called the Colonel, or something of that nature. The player must fight through the destroyable world and little brown resistance, in order to reach the end, and kill satan himself, before jumping onto a helicopter with explosions behind you.



With over 20 playable “Bros” to pick from, all coming from movies or TV in the 80s or 90s, will make any action movie fan wet themselves with nostalgia. Each character has their own special attack and primary weapon, making each one a new experience. “Bros” are unlocked by rescuing a certain number of POW’s; also doubling as lives for the player. Each time a player re-spawns, a new random unlocked character is selected, changing the play style.



One major point about the game everyone should be aware of, is the player only has 1 life point. Falling too far, or catching any bullet, will kill you. Thankfully, the enemies have a slow reaction time, and like to shoot very slow bullets; fast enough to kill you, but slow enough to jump out of the way of. The enemy's range from, massive minigun guys, to dogs, to tanks, to typical tanned jungle dwellers. The ingame environment is 90% destroyable, excluding some checkpoints and the end bit.



BroForce does some things right.



The destroyable word adds more fun into the game

The multiplayer is fantastic

The characters are fun to play

BroForce doesn't take itself seriously

Each special ability is either useful or funny in some way

Maintains a proper difficulty curve

Has a level editor

Very nostalgic

You get to kill satan



BroForce does some things wrong


The levels editor is sometimes buggy

Hard to play multiplayer with randoms

Repetitive

Still buggy

Some characters are almost useless

Lacks playing cards and achievements



All in all BroForce isn't a wonderful game, that being said, it is stupid fun and is damn good. Players can kill many hours blowing things and people up, whether you're American or not. The $16.99(CAD) price tag just isn't justifiable. If its on sale, or you really want to play with friends, pick it up

reviewText:
Broforce is a 2D Run and Gun game where you are tasked with bringing freedom to the entire world. At least that is what they claim we are doing, as we blow enemy hideouts to smithereens and fly off into the sunset. To accomplish this we are given control of “Bros” which are all parody characters out of popular films such as Rambro, Bro Hard and Bronan the Brobarian. As you can no doubt tell, this is very much a tongue in cheek type of game. Broforce is centered around fast gameplay, epic guitar riffs and destruction above all else and has very little story to speak of. You and up to three friends can join in on the carnage via drop in, drop out online or local coop to deliver fiery freedom to terrorists. Starting off the game you will have the choice of either picking Campaign or Arcade Mode. They are mostly the same except campaign mode gives you an overworld while arcade is just back to back missions. Then you will be given the choice of normal and hard difficulty. It is suggested to start on normal since hard has faster rates of fire, more enemies and placements designed to annoy you.

At the start of each mission you are given a random Bro that you have unlocked and must make your way throughout the levels saving new Bros for extra lives. Bros all play differently from one another and each have special attacks. For example one bro may only have his fists and be able to send projectiles back at enemies, while another bro throws dynamite and is able to attract enemies via a cooked turkey with dynamite stuffed into it. There are also differences in speed, strength and range between them, so every Bro requires their own play-style, which makes the repetition in this game feel very minimal. To unlock more characters you have to a certain amount of Bros from their cages. The random nature in which you are given Bros is a double edged sword. On one hand you will not be able to rely on the character you are best at and only play as them throughout, but on the other hand some Bros are just not equipped for the task at hand, which will cause you to die until you are given a Bro more suited to the situation. You can retry a mission as many times as you like so it is a minor issue. Unless you are playing on IronBro mode, a permadeath mode that is unlocked later in the game and makes it so each Bro can live only once, once you lose all Bros it's game over.

To defend yourself you will have melee, ranged and special attacks. Melee and ranged can be used indefinitely while special attacks usage amount varies from character to character. Strangely enough you can only shoot horizontally, so any enemy above or below you is untouchable via weapon fire until they are on the same plane as you. That is unless you get clever with explosives or special attacks to kill them before they know what hit them. The problem with simply jumping below is that enemies have far greater range than most Bros do, so you have to get in rather close to shoot them. Since you die in a single hit that can be an unnecessarily risky move. This game does require a decent amount of foresight before going in guns blazing. You have to consider if there may be enemies hiding in the grass, if you can take out the enemies before they fire at you and shoot an explosive near you, or if it would simply be better if you punch through a wall and make your own path. There is a pleasant amount to consider before making your move and makes it all the more sweeter when you proudly stand alone in an environment torn apart by an intense battle. That is the perfect time to use the button dedicated to flexing your muscles.

Enemies have quite a bit of variety to them and range from dogs, suicide bombers and even supernatural enemies later on. They all have different means of attack and some are able to take a lot of damage. Terrorists have a certain room in which they will infinitely respawn until you destroy the ground under that door, causing them to all fall to their deaths. Sadly, AI is terrible in this game and enemies are very likely to be the cause of their own deaths. If you are spotted the enemy will just stand there and shoot at the direction he last saw you, over and over again until you kill him. The difficulty comes from the traps, enemy numbers and camera which you have no control over. Once you kill an enemy its corpse will provide cover to his friends behind it until you gib it with a few bullets, while enemy bullets can conveniently pass through the body. The camera is far too zoomed in, causing you to be killed by an enemy that was out of view or getting explosives dropped on your head that you had no way of knowing where there on occasions.

You will also face multiple vehicles like mechs, helicopters and trucks that spawn enemies from it. Out of all the vehicles you can only hijack the mechs by standing on it and pressing the melee button.  These deal some serious damage to everything it comes across, though its ability to move around is based on a very small fuel supply, so it won't last too long. Your main threats will be the crazy bosses in this game.  The amount of destruction they all cause is staggering and it is a joy to take these down. Some will not just die by shooting at it and will require some outside the box thinking. The overall amount of destruction you will see in this game is truly impressive. Nearly anything can be destroyed and the levels usually end up looking like the planet is imploding in on itself. The only things which can't be destroyed is the ground surrounding the American flag which is used as a respawn point. There is quite a bit of levels to play through on the campaign/arcade. It keeps getting crazier and crazier the further in you go until you are eventually fighting on American soil. What little dialogue there is, is delivered via text and adds nothing to the game. The only difference in campaign mode is the over-world I previously mentioned, where you can fly around and run into seagulls because why not, as well as be able to choose which levels to take on first at times.

To top it off this game supports custom maps via Steam workshop. These can also be played with friends and are just as enjoyable as the ones found in the main game. They can be downloaded right from in game and can also be saved so you can play them offline. These offer much more value to the game and are quite a few of them already. Great music is something Broforce also has, especially that final ending theme song. With its fast paced gameplay, considerable difference between Bros and various ways to tackle levels, it offers plenty of replay value even without the user made content. Its AI is unimpressive to say the least but there is a ton of fun to be had mowing them down in various ways. All levels are perfectly playable if you end up doing it solo and may even be preferable, so you know exactly what is going on, which can be pretty hard when you have three others blowing up the map. At the end of the day this is a great game that plays like a mix of Metal Slug and an extreme version of Dig Dug.  For those still unsure I highly recommend checking out the free game  The Expendabros  to get a taste of what is on offer. Highly recommended to those that like the genre, want an action packed game or simply want a fun game to play with friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bring peace and freedom to the people.. even if you have to kill them horribly for it!

Bro Force is an arcade game in the metal slug tradition, but with much more explosions, destructions ... and bros!
It´s a nod to every fan of action movies of the last twenty years as well as fans of mindless destruction in general.

You´re leading the Broforce (a collection of nearly every action hero of that time span, each with his own attack moves and weapons) through different levels filled with terrorists. While it´s mostly pure chaos, you can also use some tactics, for example blow the ground beyond enemies and use many kinds of explosives, the world is a bit minecraft like as in you can nearly destroy everything.

Besides the game beeing good fun, it is also a positive example of early access games, beeing updated on a regular basis and with many new ideas each time. It also offers different gamplay modi, even a campaign (but better don´t ask me about it´s story ^^), in the end you get to blow up bad guys for freedom, what does a bro need more??

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Any game that lets me tear through a horde of bad guys as a Terminator, then lets me tag in Indiana Jones with a high-five for some whip-swinging action, topping the whole thing off with Mister-T pitying a horde of burning fools on his way to the final flag (and red-skinned evil leader), deserves a f**king medal.

Even unfinished, Broforce is everything a platformer game should be: Explosions. Eye-catching graphics. Explosions. Really clever character and weapon designs. Highly satisfying gameplay that just doesn't seem to wear out it's welcome, no matter how many times you blast through a level. It is everything that made 90s action movies great, meshed with everything that made 90s console platformer games great. Die Hard? Demolition Man? A-Team? Contra? If any of those words gave you a nostalgia-boner, then this game is for you.

I don't recommend games very often, because frankly, the latest half-decade of products have been 98% crap. Same old shooters, same old fantasy RPGs, same old everything. This is a refreshing change to the current crop of games, and while it pays homage to a different era of gaming, it does so on its own terms, in its own way.

If you want to feel like an action hero (or a whole team of them, as the case may be), buy this. If you want to high-five your friend in co-op, buy this. If the idea of bullet-hell or explosions gets you excited, you NEED this game.

reviewText:
Broforce is a great action platformer. I don't think I will write here anything new above everything else that was already said, but this game fully deserves my +1  and besides, I just couldn't recommend it more.

It features lots of explosions, varied enemies, fully destructible environment (if you overdo it, you can annihilate everything including your way out) and bros - numerous playable characters that parody popular tough guys or gals from movies. Many of them differ wildly from one another in playstyle, and you get them at random (whenever you die or liberate a captive, the game assigns you one from the set you unlocked).

You can play alone or co-op with up to 3 friends, both online and locally. And if you have someone over at your house, they can join you anytime - even while you're in the middle of a stage, just hand them a gamepad/ keyboard and press a button - it's that easy. There is no friendly fire (you're not taking damage if a friend shoots you directly), but you can kill your co-op partner nonetheless by environment (boulder to the head after destroying the structures too much) or blow them up by triggering explosives they stand next to. But that's ok - even dying is fun in this game.  :D

Everything is fast paced and humorous. You can approach the stages in a more tactical way, or just jump around like a headless chicken & shoot all over- whichever suits you better. You will most likely die much more following the 2nd approach, but due to the random switching of bros you may luck out at some point and push through to the end while having fun all the way. There is much fun to be had - while the stages don't vary that much some may still surprise you, and the bosses are imaginative as well as challenging, ending is just perfect - completing the campaign feels extremely satisfying.

Broforce is crazy fun & provides pure, unfettered joy. It was simply designed with player enjoyment in mind :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broforce is simply a dream come true. It is a run and gun platformer that serves as a love letter to action movies. There is a large cast of action heroes from Robocop to Mad Max that all use a variety of moves to help spread freedom across the world. Whether you are going on a chainsaw massacre with Ash williams, yelling like Arnie while creating a swordquake slam as Conan, sending bullets back at enemies as Neo, or pitying the fool as Mr. T, Broforce makes you feel cooler than you actually are.

Destructible environments and force switching characters keeps the experience chaotic, fun, and full of risk-reward situations. Gaining an extra life means that you have to give up playing as Blade and will have to adapt to whatever random bro you turn into next. It would be really easy to just use Macgyver to blow up all these enemies, but doing that would make the next jump up a lot harder. Shooting these explosive barrels will make short work of enemies and open up a new path, but it could also send down deadly debris.

The main campaign has you steering a helicopter around different parts of the world to help spread freedom through a 12 gauge and explosions. The enemies are satisfying fodder, and there are some nice surprises in the form of mechs, bossfights and aliens, with more still to come. Aside from campaign there is an arcade mode that has you running and gunning with no helicopter navigation in between. There are some very early alpha versions of different race like modes that are fun, but not quite up to par with other Bro modes.

On the local co-op front, deathmatch is a clear winner. My family and friends all have fun jumping in playing with all of these outrageous action heroes. It's an experience that reminds me of Smash Bros, but with more Bro and gore.

Even though this title is Early Access it has like nothing less than non-stop fun, great polish, and awesome updates since my preorder.

Walking away from explosions, highfiving bros for slow motion, throwing satan off a cliff, disembowling enemies, shouting freedom so loud that it terrifies enemies, and so much more, can all be found in bounty in Broforce.

reviewText: Broforce is a game that is rooted deep in the arcade shooters of the past. Contra, Commando, The Revenge of Shinobi, all of these games and more were made in a time when John Rambo and John Matrix were the superheroes of the silver screen, and game developers shamelessly translated these characters again and again. Entire genres were created in pursuit of capturing the essence of Rambo in an interactive sense. The developers at Free Lives have perfected this ideal in a way that neither the official Rambo video game or Stallone’s own nostalgia trips can. Simply put, Broforce is the ur-action movie game, combining the ridiculous tone of Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon with an attention to detail that can only come with a true love for that strange and ridiculous time when Arnold and friends shooting and screaming into the forrest was the pinnacle of cinema.\n\nWant to read more? My full Broforce review is now available over at TechRaptor.net ! https://techraptor.net/content/broforce-review-anything-expendable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Without getting into too many details, Bro Force is arguably what this world needs.  Mindless fun.  Yes, it's violent.  Yes, chances are you need a particular mindset to enjoy it, but the gameplay is solid and given I'm in no ways American I can still enjoy the light-hearted humour and rarely have I encountered a game where I have laughed so much at my own mistakes and countless deaths.  The fairly constant updates to this game are groovy, too. and in some ways this game reminds me of my love for an oldie but goldie, Gunstar Heroes.  (Which still stands as one of my all time favourites...)

Seriously, don't even be concerned about the Early Access sticker on this product.  As it currently stands it has plenty of content already and is incredibly replayable.  So do yourself a favour, give it a chance and become one among the bros!

reviewText:
+ Standard gameplay is enjoyable, fast-paced and incredibly funny.
+ The Bro-roster is large and quite varied; Every bro plays a little bit different.
+ There is a button dedicated to flexing your bro-muscles.
+ It's essentially 'Team America: World Police': The Videogame.

- The Bro's RNG can really screw you if you get a Bro with more specific abilities.
- While loading times are usually very short, they can spike to a minute or more.
- The game doesn't tell you its controls; it took me until my second playthrough to figure out you can run.
- It's essentially 'Team America: World Police': The Videogame.

Despite its flaws I've had the time of my life playing Broforce. It's brutal, it's cool and it's very, very silly. I can definitely recommend picking up a 4-pack. You may not make much progress with a full team of bros shooting the place up, but you'll enjoy (almost) every second of it.

Seriously, though. This game is honestly a great game. It's simple, really: run through a fully-destructible map and slice, shoot, explode, and basically annihilate little men with masks. Even after they're dead, you can chop them up into little pieces. This game pays close, close attention to detail, like attack dogs running up and feasting on any corpse they see, or how the avatar in the corner is animated according to what your character is doing at the time.

However, it's not too long at this point: I've gotten a little more than two hours on here. Only reason why I don't have more is because I've played it offline too, so we gotta keep that in mind. My estimate is about 3-5. No idea. But honestly, give this game a go. It deserves to be fueled with Hamiltons.

TL;DR This is a great, pixel-violent, fully-destructible, American side-scrolling game that pays close attention to detail.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Listen up, Maggots!

First and foremost this game is brosome.

That's, of course, if you are into retro style games. There's a lot of bang for the buck, it requires little HD space, plays almost completely without bugs (almost? - I didn't discover any so far) and has a really nice atmosphere to the 80's kind of action punch hard, shoot fast, blow up, die hard hero.

You'll find old friends like Brobocop, Broman the Barbarian and other Snake Plisskin like characters, funny dialogues (really, there are dialogues??), and a kind of irony that will make you chuckle a lot.

However, after a while, you can sure overplay it. So, since it takes only little space on the disk - I leave it there, and grab it from time to time and now it has been a loooong time I've played it. It fits very well into the gaps of not knowing what to play because you played it all and are so fed up with it that you think you might focus on your real life again, because maybe, just maybe you're missing out on job, wife, kids, sport and food. F@ck that!

But - most and foremost: this is absolutely mindless fun, democracy, freedom, 'Murica... all taken with such self irony, that you scream every 2 seconds: open up, mofo, FREEDOM IS HERE! And I am not even American. But this one teaches you HOW to be American, truly American, 'murically American!

'Muricalously it is not the jokes you get fed up with. It's the repeating gameplay. But hell, who cares?! Just leave it, Bro, and grab it later...

best quote: ...and watch those b@stards go down in a blaze of democracy!"

It is a play it from time to time only game

reviewText: I've been watching this game intently since it was first relased on early access. I instantly fell in love with it's classic-inspired asthetics and mechanics and I was fortunate enough to be able to experience the growth of the game and community throughout the development process. All I can say now that the game is complete is that I could not be happier with the results.\n\nThis game is essentially Metal Slug directed by Michael Bay, literally on steroids, as all the characters are almost comically musclebound. Fast pased, with a high skill cap and tons of strategies for each Bro, you'll be spending hours messing around with the different characters to find your favorite. Myself being a speedrunner, I find endless replay value in games like this and I won't be stopping any time soon. I look forward to any expansions or community contribution in the future. BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Contra meets Metal Slug meets Worms.

Overall it is a side-scroller, with great movements as in a good modern platformer (on a keyboard I recommend binding Jump to the same key as Up), a button for melee attack, a button for special attack (airstrike, slow-motion, and so on), and a button for the main attack which is usually shooting in the direction the character is facing. I really like that the movements are very fluid and allow for a great variety of moves such as wall-jumping or grabbing ledges or sliding down cords.

The game is both action-packed and violent, yet subtle. The idea to switch between famous action characters with different abilities is great as it creates a lot of variety in the situations. Some characters are melee only, some characters are more suitable for picking off enemies one by one, some characters blow everything up (the levels can be destroyed, and the level design is really well thought in order to give the player solutions to progress). Each character can influence how the player approaches the next place to assault.

The levels and enemies lack some of that huge variety that the characters have, but as the updates progress there is more and more, allowing for new situations to occur and renew the fun. Although, even as it stands, the game is already very very good and well worth the investment. Easy pick-up fun that I come back to quite often. Already one of my favorite games ever.

There is a level editor, so the community will keep the game alive and with new content for a while.

It is possible to play Coop in offline (same screen) or online (might require to open ports) multiplayer. Really adds a LOT to the fun of the game. I think that two players is the sweet spot to play seriously, as if there are more players it becomes very chaotic and the levels get destroyed quickly, sometimes hindering progression.

My only complaint is that some of the early characters are dull and unoriginal in comparison to the gameplay variety and cool specials that were added later.
If you are not sure about Broforce, try out the Expandabros on Steam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game - I tell you, it is one of the entertaining and absorbing games that I have played in a long time! Yes, it is silly, exsplosive, and Mucho 'Murica!', mixed with muscle flexing, funny puns, and playful nods.

The gameplay - 10/10

Perfectly balanced - I never felt like there was a situation that was unfair or that one character was superior/lesser.

Challenging but never imposilbe - Yes, one bullet can kill you, and, Yes, there are a TON of bullets (all with your name echtched into their firey little bodies) but never are you totally out matched, though it might get a little overwhelming at times, with all the exsplosions and such. The game gives you just the right amount of freedom to tackle all of your problems the way you want, coupled with just enough randomness to make it fresh throughout the 6 or so hour campaign.

It also features excelent coop. My dad and I played through the whole campaign (somewhere between 30 to 50 maps/levels) over two nights. It was such a blast, with more laughs then our sides could take!

The level design - 10/10

The maps were excelent - Fresh, exciting, with funny little nods sprikled about here and there. The destructible makes the games a thousands times more engaging, allowing that freedom and randomness to emerge gloriously. Also with a good amount of both height and depth to the maps, (in my eys) alleviates the staleness that would, over time, set in as some other games do.

The Music - 8/10

The rhythms and beats of war drive you on, roaring loudly as you run through the fire and blood. What more could you ask for?

Price - 7/10

When I first saw this game, I had thought that the price was much to high for what it was, but that was before I look into it. After seeing a youtuber play it, just before the Summer Sale, I thought I would give it a shot. I waited for it to go on sale, picked it up, and, after playing it, felt that it's price was right. It's not too high, but if it was a little lower, I would've gotten into it a lot sonner.

My final verdict is 9/10

It is an excelent game and should be played by anyone that enjoys very well made action games.

reviewText: A masterful critical assessment of the United States' place in the post-9/11 geopolitical environment.  The philosophical underpinnings of Baudrillard and Zizek inform its paradigm, utilizing the seemingly trite medium of video gaming to deliver a thought-provoking critique of modern military power on par with the most influential works of Chomsky, Buckley, and McTiernan.\n\nThe fragility of modern masculinity is made apparent in a manner simultaneously reminiscent of the works of Michael Kimmel and Howard Warshaw.  The protagonists are simultaneously eroticized as hyper-masculine and vulnerable to the extreme, reliant on massive phallocentric hardware" to overcome unending hordes of faceless Other
date: drawing comparisons to Said and Irigaray.\n\nCloaked in simplicity
recommended: Broforce presents a profound and nuanced statement about America

voteText: and the nature of American manhood.\n\nHighly recommended."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broforce is a 2d platformer shooter developed by free lives and published by devolver digital


The Gameplay In BROFORCE you have to get to end end of the level to get either to satan to kill him or kill the boss.
To do this you have a lot of characters with all unique special abilities but there's one thing you die in one with ( well one character not).
You also have destruction which can be very helpful to skip enemies, And you have explosives which can sometimes be really dangerous to you.
Every bro feels different since they have a different style of gun and their ability.
You unlock bros by freeing em and you'll also get lives this way.
Like terminator can be invincible for a few secs if you use his super, with indiana jones you shoot etc etc.
Theres a lot of content the game already feels complete though its kinda lacking levels but there's a workshop to fix that.
There's a bit of enemy variety the bad guys just have they're soldiers they're suiciders and they're are tanky machine gun guys.
The bosses feel really creative like there one which you have to drop off the level to beat him,
which can be annoying.
I have one complaint however, You need to complete one set of stages in one go, So youll have to replay the other 2 levels if you crash at the third.
The game runs really well 60fps 100% of the time and the game controls are solid.
And there co-op which is is local and online but i dont know how good the netcode is.


Difficulty The game can be difficult at first because you have to get used to the 1 hit and you die mechanic.
Some enemy types can be annoying at moments and you'll most likely die if you get overwhelmed.
The bosses can be real difficult also but when you figured out how to kill em youll most like will not fail.


Replayability The game will take a few hours to complete after that i don't think you can replay but only if you reset or do the arcade version of campaign(which has no difference however).
The game has a workshop with some good levels haven't used it that much.
You have no achievements or stuff like that.


Audio Overall the game sounds are good not much to say about em
The games soundtrack sounds actiony and baddass.

Story Youre murica you need to kill terrorist or whatever they are, at the end of the level you find Satan kill him and you fly away as the level explodes, Oh and there are aliens at some point for reasons.
The game is filled with references like Terminator Robocop and the Matrix and more.


Graphics I really love pixel art and i love it more when it's done well and in broforce it is done well.
The characters are well designed and look like the movie characters.
There's nothing really out of place the bosses look unique.


Bugs crashes etc I've run into no crashes or bugs overall the game doesnt feel and play and look like it's in early access, but experience can differentiate.


Final verdict A explosive fun game with lots of movie references, Cool boss design, Good pixel art, Destruction, Maybe lacking a bit on the levels side of things, Good smooth controls and performance and co-op
A must buy if you like 2d platformers and challenging games.


No drama, Just Reviews.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A1eRArgmxAI

The testosterone rich action films of the 1980s and early 90s have no doubt inspired generations of game developers, providing a metric ton of material to repackage into shooters and hack and slash titles both contemporary and classic. Of course, over time those sources of inpiration have become fodder for parody and irrevrent jabs at what was once considered the pinnacle of awesome. Broforce has risen like a phoenix from the faded pixels of Contra and Metal Slug wearing the war paint of Stallone and Schwarzenegger. This side scroller cropped up on steam's early acces page three years ago and has finally emerged as a finished product, poised to flex it's biceps and set the world on fire in the name of bromance.

Broforce places you in the boots of any number of parodies of iconic action film characters from the past 35 years of action and sci-fi cinema. There is Brochete, Rambro, Snake Broskin, Brobocop and 26 other bros ready to burn, blast and blow through any anti 'Merican, ski mask wearing, AK wielding meat bag. Select a level, warm up you hammies, decorate the environment with lead and get to the chopper—wash rinse and repeat until every American can sleep soundly at night knowing that the bros have mulched every terrorist on earth.

Broforce plays like a mash up between Metal Slug, Contra and Terraria, forcing players to blow through various enemy types and rescue hostages in a completely destructable environment. Each time you spawn you take control of a random Bro. Rescuing hostages unlocks additional characters and each one has a unique weapon and a special attack with finite uses. The Brominator wields a mini gun that has to wind up before it fires and has nasty recoil that sends the player backwards. Ash Broliams has his short range boom stick that excels at shredding the environment and terrorist scumbags. Taking control over random Bros keeps players on their toes but it can also be annoying when you have character that is ill suited to the task at hand. Fighting bosses with melee focused characters can get irritating and some characters can completely break levels by making them too easy. Cherry Broling for instance has an assault rifle for a leg which can be used to fly short distances. This allows her to fly over enemys in relative safety giving enemies a lead shower or simply skipping obstacles altogether. Also, when in multiplayer, randomly swapping between character can make it difficult to keep track of who you are controlling. This leads to unnecassary deaths and some frustration. As it should be, broforce is a chaotic game and this is only magnified by adding more players to the mix. The end result is that anything more than two players becomes a handicap since your real life Bros will  be too busy felxing to notice they are blowing up barrels right next to you or causing large rocks to collapse on your player's dome. Also, when cutscenes displaying newly unlocked characters pause the action mid game ruining your rhythym and ultimately getting you killed. It's all good fun, but don't expect to progress as a well oiled unit. Also, initiating a multiplayer bromance involves navigating a terrible lobby that doesn't display the host nor who is currently in the lobby.

The real problem with Broforce is that it's mechanics are more flaccid phallus than bulging biceps and when the novelty of it's screaming rock soundtrack and goofy characters wares off you have a game that doesn't offer any challenge in terms of platforming, the gunplay has little variety since enemies are not very dynamic and  the destructible environments allow you to cheese you way through the game if you feel inclined. The main campaign I only lasts a few hours and there is a map editor to tinker with and other players creations can be downloaded but there just isn't much to ensure that the gameplay remains compelling. It's not kind of stuff that will make a god damned sexual tyrannosaurus out of anyone...

The visuals in Broforce do a great job of keeping the tone light and when all hell breaks loose, it looks fantastic to see a Jackson Pollack painting of bloody and fiery pixels engulf the screen. Vehicle designs have the same stubby cartoonish quality as the art in Metal Slug characters are also cartoony and awesomely ridiculous. It's a shame that the game offers so few environment types. The rock tunes give the game that 80's action film feel but over extended gameplay sessions they can be obnoxious.

Broforce is a solid title that is good for a few laughs and will tickle the nostalgia bone of players who grew up on games like Contra and Metal Slug and please movie buffs with it's large cast of action flick inspired bros. However, it relies too heavily on it's novelty offering up mediocre gameplay. Anyone looking for a game relying on the cheesy testosterone fueled attitude of 1980s action cinema would probably be better served by paying Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon. Broforce is a solid game that just doesn't have what it takes to live up to the classics it tries to emulate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broforce is an amusing dose of satirical patriotism with an added blast from the past appearance from over 10 action hero characters from the 1980's and beyond. The gun play is fast, colorful, with explosions and blood flying across your screen like the 4th of July fireworks show. The game has expanded a lot since it's initial appearance on steam, so it gets a plus for steady developer support. IMO this game works best with friends, where Neo, Rambo, Robocop and more can fight side by side in the middle of the Vietnamese jungles. Alone the game can begin to bore you, so consider that when going to purchase. The game is not a very demanding one graphically, so most current pc users should be able to play with no issue. Remember the game is still not finished so expect features to be tweaked and others possibly added.

Overall this game is a barrel of laughs with friends and provides a lot of value. Get used to the electric guitars playing everytime you complete a mission!

reviewText:
2D Platforming Shooter Featuring an All-Star Cast of Action Heroes!
Broforce is probably my favourite game ever. I bought it a few years ago, and despite already finishing it, I still continue to play it. The gameplay is simple; You have a character (which the game chooses at random from the 34 available) and you have to get to the end of the level. The characters are all modeled after popular action-movie characters, such as The Terminator, Rambo, and Ellen Ripley from Alien. However, each character's name is changed to include the word 'bro.' For example, the characters I just named are The Brominator, Rambro, and Ellen Ripbro.

Each character has three attacks: their primary attack, a melee attack and a special ability. Most characters have some form of firearm for their primary attack, all with varying strengths and firerates, while other characters have swords or other weaponry. Different characters have similar melee attacks, though some have special traits. For example, Predator, Machete and Ash Williams (from The Evil Dead) can scare enemies who are in proximity to the enemies that you killed. The special abilities are where the characters vary the most, and these abilities can really give you an edge on your opponents. The abilities vary from airstrikes, lightning strikes, missile barrages, and even deflecting bullets.

The game's graphics look great. The pixel graphics match the light-heartedness of the game, and the colours used really reflect what is happening in the environment. The sounds match the game well too. All the weapons sound good, and the explosions always sound glorious. The music is simple action-movie music with a heavy drumbeat. Although this matches the theme of the game, it doesn't really add anything.

The game also features three different gamemodes. The first is the Campaign, which is your standard gamemode. This mode involves completing the levels in order via the world map. The second gamemode is Arcade Mode, which is the same as Campaign Mode, except you can choose which level you start from (assuming you have completed that level before), along with removing the world map and all cutscenes. The final gamemode is the Ironbro Campaign, which is by far the hardest. In this gamemode, once you run out of lives, it's game over, and once a character dies, they will not return until game over.

PROS
The game is certainly fun to play, and never loses its charm.
All the characters feel different, and are fun to play as (no matter how many times I blame a character when I die)
The game mixes up the environment occasionally, sending you into jungles, cities, underground, and even to Hell!
The achievements are challenging to earn, especially the character specific ones.
Broforce's difficulty slowly increases as the game goes on, allowing you to improve as the game gets harder.
There is a boss fight at the end of every mission, which are all unique and difficult in their own way.
The ending (no spoilers)
Killing birds on the World Map screen is a good stress-reliever.
Level editor with Steam Workshop support.
Up to 4-player co-op.
CONS
Sometimes the deaths seems unfair, and make you question how you actually died.
This isn't really that negative, however I would've liked some more variety in music.
Some characters appear much more often than others, which means that you don't get to see some of your favourites very often.
Summary:
I've loved this game since the first time I played it. I'd recommend this game to anyone that enjoys 2D shooters, action heroes, or action games. Even after you complete the campaign, there are still more things to do, like playing levels from the workshop or attempting the Ironbro Campaign.

Rating:
I'd give Broforce a 10/10, as this game certainly Terminates the competion.

Far and away the most satisfying game I have played in the last ten years.

Broforce is a mechanical anomaly in terms of play and style--the game actually uses a tastefully simple, super sleek, platformer base to deliver an accurate recreation of what happened in your head as you played with your action figures as a kid.

This kind of game is the reason I play video games, and the world needs more of its breed. Badly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Broforce was a game which I had watched people play on YouTube and thought it was just another fancy platformer shooter game with the added twist of action adventure movie heroes. While the game is exactly all of those things, it also has many other redeeming points.

The gameplay is overwhelmingly simple. There is nothing wrong with an easy game to play. I for one enjoy games where you can pick it up and play no matter what mood you are in. The fast paced action makes for a brilliant casual game to play when you have a few minutes to kill.

Storywise, there is none. From what I gather anyway. It's just a matter of shooting through hoards and hoards of bad guys and saving your chums who have been kept prisoner. The reward system is based on how many prisoners you actually rescure, and the rewards you get equate into new playable characters, or Bros". You start off with being able to play Rambo and you work your way through to the likes of Conan the Barbarian

Broforce is a masterpiece

Not only is this game able to compete with games such as Bioshock Infinite and Call of Duty, but it surpasses them in every single way.

This game's storyline made me cry due to the pure depth and connection to the characters I felt. I almost felt as if Conan the Brobarian was my own flesh and blood. I couldn't believe how well made this game was.

The plot is deep, having you plunged into the war against terror as one of many iconic war heroes, such as the Terminator, Blade, and Chuck Norris.

The gripping campaign had me on the edge of my seat for hours, unknowing of what twist will happen next.

I can say that Broforce is probably the greatest game I own on Steam. Not only is it the most visually beautiful, but it is the most American game I have ever played. I love Obama.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn Broforce's arcade-style campaign, or its suite of alternate modes, you take on the role of a randomized bro and kill your way across jungles and cities, aiming for an exit point or a boss fight. The way you get there is at your discretion, though. The terrain gets blasted away by your weaponry the same as any enemy; in keeping with the Minecraft/Spelunky zeitgeist, tunneling through 20 feet of concrete with a shotgun is as valid a way to the level's end as any other. Such freedom opens up some interesting strategic possibilities, like shooting the floor out from underneath an otherwise imposing foe. It also makes for some zany, unpredictable runs, especially when you're paired with trigger-happy teammates who don't give much thought to blowing up the platform you're standing on. The campaign can be taken online, and there are a few local multiplayer diversions on offer, like a player-versus-player deathmatch, and another variant that sees characters fleeing an encroaching blast from the left side of the screen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a nutshell, Broforce is Contra with a destructible environment. Throughout every level, you are one bullet away from death, but the run n' gun gameplay, along with the large variety of weapons and characters to play as, will ensure that you have a multitude of ways to complete your objective. The game takes its inspiration from various action movies, so you can expect to play as Will Smith from MIB, Ripley from the Alien series, or even Chuck Norris from Walker, Texas Ranger! This is the perfect game to play with a group of friends (up to 4 player online and local co-op), and if you get tired of the main story or deathmatch, there is a level editor to create your own masterpiece. This game is simply too much fun to pass up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A bombastic multi-player shooter that evokes the golden age of the arcades.


Broforce features simplistic 2D graphics and is a cooperative multi-player side scrolling shooter/ platformer - it could easily have been a late 80's arcade game - one of the deluxe cabinets with 4 sets of controls - the kind of Gauntlet-style set up that had coin money written all over it. Get some friends and a steady supply of coins and you'd get multi-player gaming action unparalleled at the time.

Given that this is 2014, that Broforce could be perceived as a 1980's game could be considered as a knock, but Broforce so boldly embraces the old school, so lovingly evokes the spirit of 80's and 90's action games and movies, that it feels brilliantly refreshing.

Everything is pared down to focus on out and out, balls to the wall action. With little in the way of presentation or story you begin the game as a randomly selected Bro, an often charming parody of a popular 80's/90's action hero with parodies of Robocop, Rambo,Terminator and Ellen Ripley included to name just a few, each with a custom weapon load out and a distinct play style.

The aim of the game is to battle your way through the end of each tightly constructed and enemy laden level, take out the oddly weak and passive demon suited guys that wait at the end and leap onto a helicopter ladder to escape to glory. On the way you'll find other captured Bros in cages; free them and you take on their persona, your prior Bro being saved as a 'life', a well implemented system that ensures you're encouraged to try all the different gameplay styles each Bro offers, rather than just sticking with a well-worn favourite.

The side scrolling 2D gameplay is beautifully measured, with each tiny but perfectly formed Bro sprite capable of running and jumping with a Super Mario Bros like precision, whilst wielding an awesome array of weapons with slick gun play akin to Metal Slug, Contra, and Gunstar Heroes.

Broforce is already a potent mix with those attributes but it ramps up the ante by having almost fully destructible environments with some of the best explosions seen in any game, or in any medium for that matter. They've fully captured the excessively destructive spirit from their beloved influences. Many of Broforce's explosions are simply put, epic.

One hastily thrown grenade could just as likely lead to a chain reaction and blow yourself up as it could take out an enemy, so this explosive element quickly becomes integral to the gameplay, leading to some surprisingly tactical play options depending on what Bro you may be playing at that time.

The armed enemy forces are simple but varied fodder, that can regardless still handily punish any careless Bro, with a selection of well realised and balanced bosses featured at the end of selected levels. The varying play styles of each Bro offer different ways to tackle each enemy - one Bro might simply blow up the platform the enemy stands on - one might jump and shoot from long range - one might attack from close range with melee - there really are a lot of ways to approach each scenario.

But the true mayhem ensues when playing the drop-in, drop-out online multiplayer. Up to 4 players can co-op and it is in this mode that some of the best fun is to be had. Much of the time you'll be unwittingly exploding the hell out of one another, as screen filling explosions erupt and Bros fall to their doom, often with hilarious (or infuriating) results.

Though it's just as likely to get a cohesive team and it soon becomes evident what a great co-op game this can be, each Bro can complement the other, and with 4 at once from a huge range of Bros, it's rare you'll encounter the same combo twice offering a great deal of variety.

Still an early access game, Broforce offers many other modes at varying stages of completion and even offers a custom level design utility, with hundreds of custom maps ready to play and many more appearing on the horizon.

Even at this early stage, Broforce offers a lot for the asking price and is definitely one of the most promising early access games yet released.

Unfinished it may be but it offers almost instant gameplay gratification - no fuss, no filler, just good old school explosive arcade action.


(Final score reserved for release of final retail version.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I usually tend to stay away from Early Access games on Steam, but Broforce has been calling to me.  I haven't heard anybody that's played it that didn't like it, so I gave it a shot and man...I love it!  With my limited experience with E.A., this has to be one of the best 'non-complete' games I've played yet.

The game play is straight forward and simple; rescue bros, shoot bad guys, blow ♥♥♥♥ up!  And man, it is so fun.  The terrain is highly destructible, so your sense of causing utter destruction is really grand.

While the game play itself is simple, the games difficulty is quite tough.  You will die, frequently.  You're going to swear a lot too. But with the game's restart feature, it's painless to just keep coming back and trying over and over until you can get through to the end.  Different unlocked bros have different skills as well. Some are shot guns, some are machine guns, some have grenades, some have knives.  They each add a great little spin on the game to keep it fresh and exciting. And on top of all that?  This game's pretty funny too!

Now again, this is Early Access.   So the game's incomplete.  Which blows my mind, because in its current state, Broforce is a blast.  (Pun intended.) The developers, Free Lives, are adding content to this regularly, so there's also no fear of this becoming abandoned.  Just last week they added two new bros and some game play tweaks to go with them.  It's a really solid outfit and if this isn't on your wish list yet, I'd add it a.s.a.p!

reviewText:
Campaign Beaten - 85 % Through Single Player Levels (There are extra ones) - 7 Hours.

Broforce is Brotastic. It is EASILY one of the best designed action-focused sidescrollers I have EVER played.

Concept / Elevator Pitch - A retro (artisticly) inspired side-scroller whereby you play as one of a HUGE roster of 70's/80's/90's inspired action personas/characters (names changed to be BRO" themed).  Each character has his/her own weapons/playstyle that you use to get to the end of the level. On the way
date: you will kill all sorts of bad dudes.  Missions (usually) are in clumps of 4-5 levels.\n\nThe twist: So in levels
recommended: there are "hostages" that look a LOT like homages to metal slug hostages. Rescue one
hoursPlayed:
and you get one extra life starting from the nearest checkpoint. The twist is you become a different BRO from the varied list of unlocked characters. This also happens when you die.

Furthermore....
-4 player coop
-Basically unlimited levels (community built).
-A level editor
-Harder modes if you ever (how could you) find it too easy.
- Levels are physics-based and are fully destructable. Want to avoid an enemy? Shoot a path under it.

Cons
- Really none. It is damn near perfect."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quick Breakdown: An ultra-destructible 2D action game that takes heavy influence from Contra, (though without the difficulty), and lets you play as various action heroes. This game is basically the 80’s with more testosterone.
Length: 3 hours
Score: 8/10
Review Date 2015-04-02 (Early Access)

Full Review: Broforce is a game very much influenced by 80’s action movies. As a fan of this kind of movie (though I’ve not seen all the ones this game takes influence from), it’s a pretty fun thing to play.

The gameplay is pretty simple; it’s a 2D shooter that takes a lot of influence from Contra. That said, it’s also a lot easier of a game. You move left to right, shooting your enemies, and destroying the environment. In fact, that’s part of the fun. Everything goes boom, and you can destroy most of the environment. If one path through a level isn’t working out so hot for you, you can blow up some of the terrain and see if you can go around.

The character you play as dies in one hit, so you do need to show some caution while playing, but thankfully not too much, allowing you to still run into danger with a headstrong reckless abandon. You start each level with one life, but you can collect more in the level, you’ll receive one extra life every time you rescue a bro.

And that’s one of the things we need to focus on for this review. The bros. Each bro is based on various characters from different movies, tv shows, and even comics; and each one plays differently. Most of the bros are based on 80’s action movie heroes, but we’re also treated to characters from earlier and later time periods. The core mechanics for the bros give you a main attack, which you can use as much as you want, and a special attack, which you have only a limited number of (1-6, depending on the bro).

The levels have cages scattered throughout them, containing captured bros. Each time you rescue a bro the game will automatically switch your character to a random bro, and give you another life. You unlock new brows to play as by increasing the total number of bros you’re rescued. When you die in a level, you’ll re-spawn from the last checkpoint as another random bro.

All this talk of bros begs the question, who are the bros featured in this game? Well, I won’t list all of them since part of the fun is being surprised, but I will talk about a few of them. When you first start the game, you play as Rambro (yes, all the bros have “bro” in their name, usually as a pun on either their name, or their franchise’s name). This is of course a pretty solid choice to begin the game with. Both as he’s an iconic action hero, and in game he’s armed with a machine gun and grenades, making it easy to dive right into the action and get to shooting.

As for the other bros, I was quite happy to see that Bro Hard (John McClane) included, and they even left him barefoot, which is a pretty nice touch. I was also pretty happy (and surprised) to see Bro Dredd (Judge Dredd) included, who’s gun fires bullets that both have (limited) homing abilities, and bounce off walls, (another nice touch, managing to incorporate two of his bullet types from the comics, heat-seeking and ricochet). Another fun one I was happy to see (though much less surprised) was Robrocop. The Terminator also makes an appearance, with a powerful gatling gun, and he’s a lot of fun to play as. Some of the other bros (with their non-broified names) included are Snake Plissken (Escape From New York), Blade (Marvel Comics), Men In Black, Neo (The Matrix), Indiana Jones, and quite a few others.

So, let’s talk about some of the weapons the different bros have. Machine guns are par for the course, with quite a few bros packing rapid fire heat. Others have more unique firearms, with shotguns, homing shots, spread guns, and more populating the game’s arsenal. Others opt for more literal firearms, and by that I mean a flamethrower. While others take less modern weapons, such as swords, knives, and whips; still others go for the future route, with high tech lasers and futuristic guns. And some simply prefer to do their dirty work with just their fists. As for some of the special weapons available for use, the bros are equipped with things like grenades, cluster bombs, Molotov cocktails, more powerful gun attacks, the ability to call down an air strike, and even a giant exploding turkey. The weapon variety is a lot of fun, and along with the selection of bros, is one of the game’s greatest strengths. Though sadly, some of the bros are less effective than others. Sometimes the difference is small, and sometimes it’s quite large.

The game’s graphics are done in a simple pixel art style, in the vein of old school shooters, though it looks a bit more polished than those of yore. They’re pleasant to look at, and I don’t have any real complaints about them.

The story and the setting for the game are pretty simple, you’re sent into a war zone, and must fight for freedom. It feels a bit too “America, ♥♥♥♥ yeah” for me at times, but it’s easy to overlook once you start shooting and making things go boom again. The final levels in the game pit you against alien invaders from another world, clearly inspired by the Alien franchise. (And they are the best levels in the game).

The game also features support for multiplayer fun, and while I only took a brief excursion into this myself, it was pretty good fun.

I should also note that while you can play the game with a keyboard, this is one of those games that is far better when played with a controller. As such, I’d highly recommend using an X-Box 360 controller for Windows when playing Broforce.

Now, the game itself is very short. The campaign mode will only take about a mere 3 hours to play through, and while it’s a lot of fun, it does leave one wanting for more. Thankfully, the game is still early access, so we should get more levels in the future. Even if we don’t, the game is still a blast, and certainly worth playing, but at its current length it’s probably better to pick it up on sale, instead of paying the full $15 for it. That said, the new levels that were added just before I purchased the game (the Alien Infestation update) were thrilling, and while there weren’t too many of those included, they were easily some of the best in the game. If this is the kind of content that future updates will be, then I very eagerly look forward to more.

If you’re still not quite sure on if you should pick up Broforce or not, you could grab The Exependabros on Steam for free. It’s a game that features characters from The Expendables 3, but set in Broforce style levels. It’s not as good as the actual Broforce game, but it works pretty well as a demo if you need a little convincing before plunking down your cash for this one. (Or if you simply need more Broforce action after completing this game, go grab it for a quick hour long romp).

When all’s said and done, Broforce is a hell of a lot of fun, and being able to fight your way across levels as an assortment of different characters with different weapons is quite enjoyable. Give it a chance, start blowing ♥♥♥♥ up with your favourite action heroes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOne of the funnest games I have played in a while.  No grinding, no flag-collecting, no crappy story with unskippable cutscenes, just play and have fun. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I grew up in the 90s on a steady stream of the best-worst action movies. They were over the top, stupid, and loud as hell- Everything America stands for. And they were great.

BROFORCE toes the same line as many of those old action flicks.  It's a celebration of testosterone, bullets, and bombs, taken to the nth degree +1. If Stephen Colbert and Torgue Flexington developed a game, it would come out a lot like this.

And it's magnificent.

The controls are better than you'd think with a keyboard. They're tight. Responsive. It takes getting used to, and a controller would be better, but it's not bad.

The gameplay is simple and open-ended in a great way. You could go all out and dive straight in like a madman. You could take your time and pick out the best possible attack route... Or you could defeat your enemies by exploiting the environment, which is the most patriotic way.

All that aside, BROFORCE is one of the few games I've played in a while that's just plain fun. No intricate plot. No dark, brooding hero. No 'LOOK AT HOW GRIMDARK AND BROWN THE WORLD IS, BLOO BLOO BLOO'. You shoot, stab, and explode your way through everything ( including your friends ) in a colorful world, and laugh the whole time.

Awesome.

reviewerDisplayName: His Name is Easy to Remember
reviewText: Make no mistake! Behind the poor name lies an action standalone great. Effing simple to learn, this is a platformer at its core. It has lots of action, explosions, and gunplay. One of my favorite parts is all of the Bros. The developers took inspirations for some of the action movie greats, including Terminator, Robocop, Aliens, Timecop, Boondock Saints, Rambo, Commando, the A Team, Walker Texas Ranger, Blade, Judge Dredd, Men In Black, Metal Gear solid, Indiana Jones, Evil Dead, The Matrix, Machete, Conan, Universal Soldier, Mad Max, and more! I also really liked fighting the xenomorphs (aliens). They looked, bled, and died like Ripley's bad guys, eggs and all. If a facehugger gets you, you inflate like a balloon, pop, and out comes an alien. You have an unlimited primary weapon and a limited secondary weapon. You don't take damage, but rather die, and out pops a new Bro! POWs can be given weapons and used as soldiers. Captured Bros lie waiting in cages--the more you free, the more Bros you unlock for use. I have to agree with the vast majority of other gamers who give this a thumbs-up and some playtime.

reviewText:
LAND OF THE FREE HOME OF F--KING SHT UP, BRO

This is a game where a controller is not only highly recommended, I wouldn't even bother without one. It is not meant for keyboard controls in the slightest. One of the best dollar-to-fun ratio's I've ever had on steam. The $11 I paid for this was a steal. One of the most fun experiences you can have playing online. The single player is also incredible. The game is hilarious and lots of action movie badasses are in it, my favs probably being Snake Plissken and Ash Williams. Game is VERY fun and very well made. Constant explosions, gunfire, and death. It is pure insanity non-stop. The controls are somewhat loosey goosey but it is not a true platformer and does not have spike traps/death traps on every inch of ground so the slightly loose control is okay after you get used to it and get better at the game which shouldn't take long. The game will be very frustrating at times though so you really need some good skills to finish without retrying lots of times and even when you do it's still fun. Everything is done well too. The sounds, music, new-age retro graphics, art direction, gameplay, enemies hilarious screams, weapons, levels, and effects are all solid. It has enough explosions and killing for the biggest action movie fan in the world (pretty much me) so you need to buy this and get in game and be a man and completely demolish entire levels with your manly instruments of pain.

Be a man, pony up the dough for this game, and add me so we can do a high five that shakes mountains like Schwartzenegger and Carl Weathers did at the beginning of Predator. Firin' rockets like a god damn boss, son.

9/10 BOSS MODE, SON!

Protip #1 - Buy this
Protip #2 - Add me so we can jam
Protip #3 - Show no mercy

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh, I didn't see you there. I was just liberating a group of half-starved terrorists in a third-world cesspool. They were sitting there, bleary-eyed, and I tossed a fully stuffed chicken in front of them. The big fat one in the front of the group, you could see the saliva dripping out of his dry, cracked lips. They rush it, like little cockroaches. Scurrying over anything in their way just to reach this magical bird that had suddenly fallen out of the sky. Just as they reach it, BOOM. Freedom dispensed. All that is left is a smoking crater and some assorted body parts, like I'm in some weird butcher shop in backwoods Africa.

Get this game. Do you want to toss a dynamite-stuffed turkey into a group of balaclava-wearing terrorists? Broforce can help you with that. Kill a suicide bomber and toss his explosive-laden body into a group of his friends? Yup, Broforce has your back. What about flying through the sky while shooting a minigun just in time to escape certain death? You guessed it, Broforce.

Thanks to Broforce, I am now a liberty dispensing, freedom fighting, USA machine!

reviewText:
Broforce is overloaded with action and explosions action with up to 4 players (online or local).

Good+ loads of action
+ fully (almost) destructible levels
+ steam play (win/lin/osx)
+ steam workshop
+ many references to 198x-199x movies
+ humor
+ many characters
+ each character has it's own strong/week points
+ flying pigs

Bad- horrible lags in online coop (probably game doesn't get in account how far players are)
- kinda repetitive (but it's 'based' on action movies from 80-90, what else do you expect?)

Bottom line: Get 4pack and have fun with your friends in hilarious local/online coop mayhem!

reviewText:
A superb 2D platformer that oozes humour and references pretty much every single action movie ever made.

Graphically it looks beautiful for what it attempts to emulate (the 8/16-bit era) and the controls and movement are silky smooth and work wonderfully. It also features local co-op and a built in level editor which is also an amazing amount of fun.

The gameplay consists of running through various zones rescuing your comrades and shooting the bad-guys. Get to the choppa!" It has destructible terrain
date: tons of playable characters (each with their own distinct abilities and weapons)
recommended:
bonkers bosses and 'MERICA to the extreme.

Truly a joy to play and I would recommend to anyone interested in it.

Jimbo Rating: 8/10"

reviewText:
Do you like action games that rely on stealth and subtlety? Games with deep plotlines that make you think? Complex characters with ambigious moral values?

THIS IS NOT THAT KIND OF GAME, MAGGOT!

Broforce is gratuitus violence and bloodshed! You will kill terrorist scumbags and thier mook lackies, in violent and creative ways (gunfire, punching enemies until thier corpses explode in bloody chunks, turkeys filled with dynamite, and more) and you will like it soldier! Broforce is unashamed machismo and testosterone! Your general is an xenophobic American bigot...hell yeah soldier! You will play as many muscle mound, steroid swollen men (and women) and your warlike musk will be the first sign to the terrorists that you are there...before bullets and explosions blow them away! Broforce is war motherflippah! You will face mooks, missile firing tanks, and vear-hecles that spew out terrorist scum, and you will have at your disposal guns, kung fu fists of fury, dynamite, missile launchers, shotguns, chainsaws, flamethrowers, swords, and mech suits armed and armoured to the teeth! You will use your enviroment with guile and skill, scalling walls, shooting explosive barrells to kill nearby enemies, dropping bee hives onto enemies heads, and destroying earth to bring down buildings on enemies heads.

This is a mindless action game at its glorious best. If you like this kind of thing...your a sick individual and I highly reccomend this game to you.

4/5 Severed terrorist heads

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pixel art at it's finest i would say. The game is currently still on Early Access, but has a lot going for it to buy it right now. There are currently a total of 19 Bros (characters) in the game you can play as. From Rambro to Brobocop, and each has their own unique abilities.

The missions you take on are pretty straight forward, kill every enemy in the level and get out. On your way you can rescue survivors, these will help you towards unlocking new characters, but also count as extra lives during that level. Plus you can pretty much destroy everything in the level. which is always a fun thing to do.

As i mentioned the game is still being worked on and there is still a lot to come to make it even better. If you like pixel art and shooting things up while playing as Chuck Norris or Rambo then you should already have gotten the game, if not then i would highly recommend you grab a copy of the game. It's Brotastic.
